questions.q: How many calories per gram does fat provide?
questions.rationale: Fat is the most calorie-dense macronutrient at 9 calories per gram.

questions.q: Which food is a complete protein source?
questions.rationale: Eggs contain all 9 essential amino acids and are considered a complete protein.

questions.q: Which vitamin is NOT fat-soluble?
questions.rationale: Vitamin C is water-soluble. Fat-soluble vitamins are A, D, E, and K (remember: ADEK).

questions.q: Water-soluble vitamins are excreted by which organ?
questions.rationale: Water-soluble vitamins are filtered and excreted by the kidneys in urine.

questions.q: A deficiency of Vitamin A causes which condition?
questions.rationale: Vitamin A is critical for rhodopsin production in the retina; deficiency leads to night blindness.

questions.q: Vitamin D deficiency in children causes which condition?
questions.rationale: Rickets is caused by Vitamin D deficiency in children, leading to soft and deformed bones.

questions.q: A patient on Warfarin should be cautious with which food?
questions.rationale: Kale is high in Vitamin K which antagonizes Warfarin's anticoagulant effect.

questions.q: Which enhances iron absorption?
questions.rationale: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) converts ferric iron to ferrous iron, enhancing absorption in the gut.

questions.q: Which food is highest in potassium?
questions.rationale: Bananas are one of the most well-known high-potassium foods at ~422 mg per medium banana.

questions.q: A patient with heart failure should follow which diet?
questions.rationale: Heart failure patients need sodium restriction (typically 2g/day) to prevent fluid retention and edema.

questions.q: A patient on hemodialysis needs which dietary modification?
questions.rationale: Dialysis patients need increased protein to replace losses during dialysis treatments.

questions.q: The DASH diet is recommended for which condition?
questions.rationale: DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) is specifically designed to lower blood pressure.

questions.q: Which macronutrient most affects blood glucose?
questions.rationale: Carbohydrates are broken down into glucose and have the most direct impact on blood sugar levels.

questions.q: A BMI of 27 falls into which category?
questions.rationale: A BMI of 25-29.9 is classified as overweight.

questions.q: Before administering a tube feeding, the nurse should FIRST:
questions.rationale: Verifying tube placement is the priority safety measure before any tube feeding to prevent aspiration.

questions.q: TPN is administered via which route?
questions.rationale: TPN is hypertonic and must be administered through a central venous line to prevent vein damage.

questions.q: A patient with dysphagia should avoid which item?
questions.rationale: Thin liquids are the most aspiration-prone consistency for patients with dysphagia.

questions.q: Soluble fiber has which primary benefit?
questions.rationale: Soluble fiber forms a gel that binds bile acids and helps lower serum cholesterol levels.

questions.q: Which lab is the BEST short-term indicator of nutritional status?
questions.rationale: Prealbumin has a half-life of 2-3 days, making it the most sensitive short-term marker of nutritional status.

questions.q: Which nutrient prevents neural tube defects?
questions.rationale: Folic acid is essential for neural tube closure in the first 28 days of development.

questions.q: A neutropenic patient should avoid which food?
questions.rationale: Fresh raw salads carry bacteria risk; neutropenic patients should eat only cooked or processed fruits and vegetables.

questions.q: Which nutrient is essential for collagen formation in wound healing?
questions.rationale: Vitamin C is a cofactor for collagen synthesis, which is essential for wound healing and tissue repair.

questions.q: When hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia coexist, the nurse should correct which first?
questions.rationale: Magnesium must be corrected first because hypomagnesemia prevents potassium from being retained by the kidneys.

questions.q: Phosphorus has an inverse relationship with which electrolyte?
questions.rationale: Phosphorus and calcium have an inverse relationship: when one rises, the other falls.

questions.q: Pernicious anemia results from a deficiency of:
questions.rationale: Pernicious anemia is caused by lack of intrinsic factor, which is needed for B12 absorption in the terminal ileum.

questions.q: A patient with celiac disease must avoid which grain?
questions.rationale: Barley contains gluten, which triggers the autoimmune response in celiac disease.

questions.q: At what age can a child begin drinking whole cow's milk?
questions.rationale: Whole cow's milk is introduced at 12 months; before that, breast milk or formula provides optimal nutrition.

questions.q: The minimum acceptable urine output for an adult is:
questions.rationale: A minimum urine output of 30 mL/hr (or 0.5 mL/kg/hr) indicates adequate renal perfusion in adults.

questions.q: A patient scheduled for surgery at 0800 should stop eating solids by:
questions.rationale: Standard NPO guidelines require stopping solid foods 6-8 hours before surgery; midnight is the traditional cutoff for an 0800 surgery.

questions.q: Which is the primary function of Vitamin E?
questions.rationale: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant that protects cell membranes from oxidative damage by free radicals.
